model_completion: Born in 1957, Mukesh Ambani is the chairman and managing director of Reliance Industries Limited (RIL). He is also the chairman of Reliance Jio Infocomm Limited (RJIL), which was launched in September 2016. Ambani is the son of Dhirubhai Ambani, who founded RIL in 1966. In 2008, he became the richest person in India, with a net worth of $43 billion.

Massimo Vignelli was born in Milan, Italy in 1931. He studied architecture at the Politecnico di Milano and later moved to New York City. In 1960, he founded his own design firm, Vignelli Associates, with his wife Lella. The firm has designed many iconic logos, including those for American Airlines, Bloomingdale's, Ford Motor Company, IBM, and the New York Subway System. Vignelli died on May 27, 2014.

Born in Zanzibar, Tanzania, on September 5, 1946, Freddie Mercury was the lead singer and songwriter for the rock band Queen. He died of AIDS-related complications on November 24, 1991. His songs include "Bohemian Rhapsody," "We Are the Champions," and "Don't Stop Me Now."

Socrates was born in Athens, Greece in 469 BC. He was an Athenian philosopher and teacher who lived during the Classical Period of Ancient Greece. His most famous student was Plato. Socrates believed that people should question everything, including their own beliefs. He also believed that people should be honest and just. Socrates was put on trial for corrupting the youth of Athens. He was sentenced to death by drinking poison hemlock.

Born in Sighet, Romania, on September 30, 1928, Elie Wiesel was the son of Shlomo and Sarah Wiesel. His father was a shopkeeper and his mother was a homemaker. In 1944, when he was 15 years old, Wiesel and his family were deported to Auschwitz-Birkenau, where his mother and sisters died. He survived the Holocaust and later became an author and activist. Wiesel has written more than 50 books, including 'Night,' which won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986.

Born in Chicago, Illinois, on July 21, 1951, Robin Williams was the youngest of three children. His father was an automobile mechanic and his mother was a model. He attended Redwood High School in Larkspur, California, where he was a class clown. After graduating from high school, he went to Claremont College, but dropped out after one year. In 1973, he moved to San Francisco, where he began performing stand-up comedy at clubs. In 1978, he made his film debut in 'Popeye.' Since then, he has appeared in many films, including 'Good Morning, Vietnam,' 'Mrs. Doubtfire,' 'The Birdcage,' and 'Good Will Hunting.' He won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his role in 'Good Will Hunting' (1997).

Born in Calcutta, India, Amartya Sen was educated at Presidency College and the University of Delhi. He received his PhD from Trinity College, Cambridge in 1959. In 1972, he became a professor at Harvard University, where he taught until 1978. He then returned to Cambridge as a professor of economics and philosophy. In 1998, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economics for his work on welfare economics.

Born in Toronto, Canada, Isadore Sharp founded the Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts in 1960. He started with one hotel in Toronto, and now owns over 85 hotels worldwide. In 2007, he was named as the richest Canadian by Forbes magazine.

Born in Bristol, England, on February 3, 1821, Elizabeth Blackwell was the first woman to receive a medical degree in the United States. She graduated from Geneva Medical College in New York in 1849. In 1857, she opened the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, which became the first hospital run by women. She also founded the Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania in 1850, and served as its president until 1867. Elizabeth Blackwell died on May 31, 1910.

Nobu Matsuhisa was born in Japan, and moved to the United States at the age of 18. He worked as a sushi chef in Los Angeles, California, before opening his first restaurant, Sushi Naoe, in Beverly Hills. In 1987, he opened his second restaurant, Matsuhisa, which became one of the most popular Japanese restaurants in the world. His third restaurant, Nobu, opened in New York City in 1994. Today, there are over 30 Nobu restaurants around the world.

Born in 1973, Larry Page was the co-founder of Google with Sergey Brin. He attended the University of Michigan and received his PhD from Stanford University. In 1998, he and Brin founded Google, which became one of the most successful companies in the world. In 2011, Page became CEO of Google, and in 2015, he announced that he would be stepping down as CEO to focus on other projects.

Winona LaDuke was born in 1959, and grew up on the White Earth Indian Reservation in Minnesota. She attended Harvard University, where she received her Bachelor's degree in Economics. In 1983, she founded the White Earth Land Recovery Project, which works to protect Native American land from development. In 1986, she ran for Vice President on the Green Party ticket with Ralph Nader. She has also written several books, including 'All Our Relations: Native Struggles for Land and Life,' and 'Last Standing Woman.'

Greta Gerwig was born in Sacramento, California on August 4, 1983. She attended Barnard College and the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. In 2012, she made her directorial debut with the film 'Frances Ha,' which she also wrote. The movie received critical acclaim and won the Best Screenplay award at the 2013 Independent Spirit Awards.

José Alberto "Pepe" Mujica Cordano was born on May 20, 1935 in Montevideo, Uruguay. He is the current President of Uruguay and served as its Vice-President from 2005 to 2010. In 1961, he joined the Tupamaros guerrilla movement, which fought against the military dictatorship that ruled Uruguay at the time. He was arrested in 1974 and sentenced to 12 years in prison. After his release in 1985, he became a senator and later a congressman. In 2004, he founded the Broad Front coalition, which won the presidential election in 2009.

Born in 1992, Hideki Matsuyama is a Japanese professional golfer. He was the youngest player to win on the Japan Golf Tour at age 16. In 2013, he became the first Asian-born player to win an official PGA event when he won the Memorial Tournament.

Born in 1989, Alex Morgan is an American soccer player and Olympic gold medalist. She was the youngest member of the U.S. women's national team that won the gold medal at the 2012 Summer Olympics. In 2013, she became the first woman to score a goal in a FIFA World Cup final.

Born in 1797, Sojourner Truth was the daughter of an African-American slave and a white farmer. She was born Isabella Baumfree, but later changed her name to Sojourner Truth. In 1826, she escaped from slavery with her infant son, and became a prominent abolitionist and women's rights activist. She gave many speeches on racial equality and women's rights, and was one of the first black women to win the right to vote. Sojourner Truth died in 1883.

Elon Reeve Musk was born in Pretoria, South Africa on June 28, 1971. He is the founder and CEO of SpaceX, Tesla Motors, and SolarCity. In 2002, he co-founded PayPal with Peter Thiel, which was later sold to eBay for $1.5 billion. In 2004, he founded Space Exploration Technologies (SpaceX), which has developed rockets and spacecraft for commercial spaceflight. In 2006, he founded Tesla Motors, which manufactures electric cars. In 2016, he founded Neuralink, a company that develops brain-computer interfaces.

Cindy Sherman was born in 1954, and grew up in Long Island, New York. She attended the State University of New York at Buffalo, where she received her BFA in 1976. In 1977, she moved to New York City, where she began her career as an artist. Her work has been exhibited in museums around the world, including the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Tate Gallery in London, and the Centre Georges Pompidou in Paris.

Born in 1957, Katie Couric was raised in Arlington, Virginia. She attended the University of Virginia and graduated with a degree in English. After graduation, she worked as an intern at NBC News. In 1989, she became a correspondent for CBS News. In 2006, she became the first female solo anchor of a network evening news program.

Born in San Juan, Puerto Rico, on March 10, 1994, Benito Antonio Martinez Ocasio, better known as Bad Bunny, is a Puerto Rican rapper and singer. He was born to a family of musicians and started his career at the age of 16. His first album, 'X 100PRE,' was released in 2017. In 2018, he won two Latin Grammys for Best Urban Fusion/Performance and Best Urban Song.

Esther Duflo was born in Paris, France on August 25, 1972. She received her PhD from MIT in 2006 and became the youngest woman to receive tenure at MIT. In 2013, she won the John Bates Clark Medal for her work in development economics. She is currently the Abdul Latif Jameel Professor of Poverty Alleviation and Development Economics at MIT.

Richard Pryor was born in Peoria, Illinois on December 1, 1940. He grew up in a poor family and dropped out of school at the age of 15. In 1963, he moved to New York City where he began his career as a stand-up comedian. His first appearance on television was on 'The Ed Sullivan Show' in 1967. He became famous for his controversial comedy style, which often included racial slurs and profanity. He also starred in several movies, including 'Silver Streak,' 'Which Way Is Up?' and 'Brewster's Millions.' Richard Pryor died on December 10, 2005 from heart failure.

Tex Avery was born in Taylor, Texas on February 26, 1908. He began his career as an animator at the Walt Disney Studios in 1935. In 1942, he joined MGM and created some of the most famous cartoons of all time, including 'Red Hot Riding Hood' and 'The Wolf Who Came to Dinner.' He retired from animation in 1957, but continued to work as a director for television shows such as 'The Flintstones.' He died on July 26, 1980.

Born in 1973, Dave Chappelle grew up in Ohio and began performing stand-up comedy at the age of 14. He was discovered by comedian Paul Mooney, who helped him get his first gigs. In 1993, he moved to New York City, where he became a regular on 'Def Comedy Jam.' His first HBO special, 'Killin' Them Softly,' was released in 2000. In 2005, he left his hit show 'Chappelle's Show' after only two seasons, citing creative differences with the network.

Born in Baghdad, Iraq, in 1950, Zaha Hadid was the first woman to win the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004. She studied mathematics at the American University of Beirut and later architecture at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London. In 1987, she established her own architectural firm, Zaha Hadid Architects, which has offices in London, New York, and Hong Kong. Her most famous works include the Guangzhou Opera House in China, the Rosenthal Center for Contemporary Art in Cincinnati, and the London Aquatics Centre for the 2012 Summer Olympics.

Mary Wollstonecraft was born in 1759, and was the daughter of an affluent London family. She was educated at home by her father, who taught her to read and write. In 1780, she married William Godwin, a philosopher and political writer. They had one daughter together, Fanny, but Mary died shortly after giving birth. Her most famous work, 'A Vindication of the Rights of Woman,' was published posthumously in 1792.

Born in 1930, Warren Buffett was raised in Omaha, Nebraska. He attended the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business and graduated with an economics degree in 1950. In 1954, he founded his own company, Buffett Partnership Ltd., which later became Berkshire Hathaway Inc. In 2006, Forbes magazine ranked him as the richest person in the world, with a net worth of $62 billion.

Born in New York City, George Carlin was an American comedian and actor. He began his career as a stand-up comedian in the 1950s, and later became known for his political satire. His most famous works include 'The Seven Words You Can Never Say on Television,' 'George Carlin: 40 Years of Comedy,' and 'Brain Droppings.' In 2008, he died from heart failure at the age of 71.

Quentin Tarantino was born in Los Angeles, California on March 27, 1963. He grew up in Tarzana, California and attended the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). In 1984, he dropped out of UCLA to pursue his career as a filmmaker. His first movie was 'My Best Friend's Birthday,' which was released in 1987. Tarantino's breakthrough came with 'Reservoir Dogs,' which was released in 1992. The movie received critical acclaim and won the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival. Tarantino's next movie, 'Pulp Fiction,' was released in 1994 and became an instant hit. It won the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay and the Golden Globe Award for Best Picture - Comedy or Musical.

Born in 1997, Simone Biles is an American gymnast who won four gold medals at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. She was the first woman to win three consecutive world all-around titles, and she has also won four Olympic gold medals. In 2013, Biles became the first female gymnast to win two World Championship all-around titles.

Born in Belgrade, Serbia, Novak Djokovic started playing tennis at the age of four. He won his first Grand Slam title at Wimbledon in 2011 and has since won three more titles. In 2011, he was named ATP World Tour Player of the Year.

Born in Russia, Ayn Rand moved to the United States at the age of 21. She became a naturalized citizen in 1931 and began writing novels. Her most famous work was 'The Fountainhead,' which was published in 1943. The book was adapted into a movie in 1949. In 1957, she wrote her second novel, 'Atlas Shrugged.' It was also made into a film in 1992.

Born in 1207, Jalaluddin Rumi was a Persian poet and Sufi mystic. He wrote the 'Mathnawi', an epic poem that has been translated into many languages. His work influenced many poets and writers, including William Butler Yeats and Walt Whitman.

Born in Romania, Constantin Brancusi was an influential sculptor who lived from 1876 to 1957. He studied at the School of Fine Arts in Bucharest and later moved to Paris, where he became famous for his abstract sculptures. His most famous works include 'The Kiss' (1907-1908), 'Bird in Space' (1923), and 'Endless Column' (1934).

James Watt was born in Greenock, Scotland on January 19, 1736. He was the son of a shipwright and an inventor. At the age of 18, he went to Glasgow University to study mathematics and science. In 1757, he became an apprentice to a instrument maker. In 1763, he moved to London where he worked as an instrument maker for Thomas Newcomen. In 1765, he returned to Glasgow and opened his own business. In 1769, he began working on improving the steam engine. His improvements made it possible to use steam engines for industrial purposes. In 1784, he patented his improved steam engine.

Born in South Africa, Christiaan Barnard was the first person to perform a heart transplant. He received his medical degree from the University of Cape Town and later moved to London for further training. In 1967, he became the head of cardiac surgery at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town. On December 3, 1967, Barnard performed the world's first human-to-human heart transplant on Louis Washkansky. The operation was successful, but Washkansky died 18 days later due to double pneumonia.

Jorge Mario Bergoglio was born on December 17, 1936 in Buenos Aires, Argentina. He was ordained as a priest in 1969 and became the Archbishop of Buenos Aires in 1998. In March 2013, he was elected as the 266th pope and took the name Pope Francis. He has been credited with bringing the Catholic Church closer to the poor and marginalized.

Born in 1970, Tina Fey is an American actress, comedian, writer, and producer. She was born in Upper Darby, Pennsylvania, and grew up in the Philadelphia suburbs. After graduating from the University of Virginia, she moved to New York City, where she worked as a writer for 'Saturday Night Live' (SNL). In 2004, she created the television series '30 Rock,' which earned her several Emmy Awards. She has also starred in movies such as 'Mean Girls,' 'Baby Mama,' and 'Date Night.'

Born in 1791, Samuel Morse was an American painter and inventor. He is best known for developing the telegraph system. In 1832, he patented his first telegraph system, which used dots and dashes to transmit messages. The telegraph was later improved by other inventors, including Thomas Edison.
